Editor's choice paper Selective hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol to phenolics over activated carbon supported molybdenum catalysts Zhe Cai a Fumin Wang a ⁎ Xubin Zhang a ⁎ Rosine Ahishakiye b Yi Xie a Yu Shen a a School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 PR China b School of International Education, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China School of International Education Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Activated carbon-supported molybdenum dioxide catalyst and molybdenum carbide catalyst were prepared by reduction in hydrogen with different temperatures. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol was investigated in 3MPa initial H2 pressure with these two catalysts. Phenolics were detected as the main products when catalyzed by molybdenum dioxide catalyst. Through analyzing the HDO selectivity of guaiacol and the intermediates including 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, catechol, phenol and anisole, the HDO reaction pathways of guaiacol over Mo-based catalysts were proposed. In the first stage, transalkylation and breaking of three CO bonds take place to produce 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, catechol, phenol and anisole, whereafter cresol, phenol, toluene and benzene are produced. Furthermore, the effects of reaction temperatures and solvents on HDO of guaiacol were investigated. Using tetralin as solvent, in 3MPa initial H2 pressure and at 573K, the conversion of guaiacol reached 98% with phenolics as the major product and the selectivity was greater than 91% after three hours of reaction time. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Guaiacol Molybdenum Reaction pathways 1 Introduction For the nonrenewable property and continuous consumption of fossil energy, there is an urgent need for renewable energies. Bio-oils can be produced via the pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass which is regarded as ideal green energy sources [1]. The pyrolysis oils are complex mixtures containing arboxylic acids, ketones, aldehydes, carbohydrates, aldehydes, furans and so on [2,3]. The pyrolysis oils are too high oxygen content to be used as fuel additions, so they must be dealed with a hydrodeoxygenation process to reduce the oxygen content and increase energy value [4,5]. Thus, two-stage upgrading strategy was proposed in which the pyrolysisi oil was produced from pyrolysis of biomass and then hydrodeoxygenation is performed to decrease the oxygen content [6]. Lignin is a very complex polymer with components including of coniferyl, sinapyl, and p-coumaryl alcohol [7]. For the study of hydrogenation of pyrolysis oils, guaiacol which is a small molecule with similar functional groups has been often studied as a model compound because of its three different oxygen-carbon bonds: C(sp3)–OAr (methoxy group), C(sp2)–OMe and C(sp2)–OH (hydroxyl) with the bond energies about 247, 356 and 414kJ/mol, respectively [8,9]. These three bonds are present in a large number of functional groups of lignin. Initial HDO catalysts referenced to the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalysts and the hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) catalysts [10]. Commercial sulfided NiMo and CoMo catalysts supported over activated alumina were applied in the research of HDO [11], while catalysts supported on activated carbon, silica, zeolite, zirconia were investigated also for this process [12,13]. Van Ngoc Bui et al. [13] reported the support effect for CoMoS catalysts on HDO activity and selectivtity where zirconia allowed very high catalytic activities and selectivity towards Carom-O hydrogenolysis. However, the sulfide catalysts are easy to be deactivated for the loss of sulfur species and the oxidation of the sulfur species to sulphate and sulphur may be introduced into product stream. [14] Early studies of noble metal catalysts have shown that such catalysts have a good activity on HDO of guaiacol. [4,9,15,16] Jingbo Mao et al. showed gold nanoparticles supported on TiO2 exhibited remarkable selectivity to phenolics from guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation [17]. Two major pathways to form phenol are proposed, (1) demethoxy of guaiacol and (2) hydrogenation of C(sp3)–OAr bond to form catechol and hydrodehydroxylation of catechol to form phenol followed. Recently, novel non-sulfurized and non-noble metal catalysts have been widely studied, including Ni, Mo, Co, Cu, Mn, W, and the like. The carbides [18], phosphides [19] and nitrides [20] of these transition metals have also been studied. Some of them have very good activity and selectivity in the HDO reactions compared to noble metal catalysts. Anna L. Jongerious et al. showed Mo2C/CNF has high conversion and selectivity towards phenolics in the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol [21]. Similarly, Rui Ma and coworkers reported selectivities of up to 85% to phenolics were obtained over α-MoC1-x/AC in supercritical ethanol [22]. Molybdenum-based catalysts show remarkable selectivity to phenolics in the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of guaiacol. In this work, molybdenum dioxide and Molybdenum carbide supported on the activated carbon were prepared as catalyst in the HDO of guaiacol. In order to investigate the effect of molybdenum catalyst on the HDO conversion and selectivity of guaiacol, the guaiacol HDO reaction pathways of guaiacol were studied firstly. Based on the analysis of the HDO products of guaiacol and its intermediates including 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, catechol, phenol and anisole, the HDO reaction pathways of guaiacol were proposed. The effects of reaction conditions on selectivity of phenolics in the HDO of guaiacol were also discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material Ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 99%), guaiacol (99.5%), catechol(99%), phenol (99.5%) and anisole (99%) were purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene (99%), ethanol (99.9), tetradecane (98%), dodecane (98%), decalin (99%)and tetralin (99%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. N2 and H2 gas were obtained from Air Liquide (China) Co., Ltd. Coconut shell carbon was obtained from the local activated carbon company and was ground to 40–60mesh as support. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared using incipient wetness impregnation method, with ammonium heptamolybdate as the precursor of Mo, coconut shell carbon as support. Before used, activated carbon was grinded, sieved into 40–60mesh, pretreated with 1M HNO3 at 353K for 8h. The solution was then filtered and extensively washed with distilled water to bring the pH to 7. The samples were dried overnight in oven at 378K. A typical preparation process of 20%wt loading Mo catalyst is that 3g AC was slowly poured into ammonium heptamolybdate solution (0.7359g ammonium heptamolybdate in 3.6ml deionized water). After impregnation, the catalyst was kept at room temperature for 2h, and then dried overnight at 378K. The obtained sample was calcined at 773K for 3h in a tube furnace with flowing nitrogen. Before HDO reaction, catalysts were reduced at 873K or 973K for 3h in 200ml/min flowing hydrogen gas. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the catalyst was carried out with Micromeritics AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 characterization equipment. Catalyst samples (100mg) were flushed with Ar at 673K. Then TPR was performed from 323K to 1173K at a heating rate of 10K/min under a flow (50ml/min) of 5% H2 in Ar. The consumption of H2 was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray diffraction patterns of the powdered samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15405nm). XRD patterns were collected in the range of 2θ from 10° to 80° with a scanning rate of 8°/min. Identification of the phases was achieved by reference to the JCPDS diffraction data file data. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were carried out on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer employing a monochromated Al-K α X-ray source (hv =1486.6eV), hybrid (magnetic/electrostatic) optics and a multi-channel plate and delay line detector (DLD). All XPS spectra were recorded using an aperture slot of 300×700μm; survey spectra were recorded with a pass energy of 80eV, and high resolution spectra with a pass energy of 40eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a JEOL JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope operating at 200kV. Before observation, the sample was ground to powder and ultrasonically suspended for 10min and then deposited on a copper grid coated with carbon film. The specific surface area (SBET), pore volume and pore size distribution of the catalysts were determined from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms measured at 77K using a NOVA 2000 analyzer. Before the measurement, samples were degassed at 383K under vacuum for 4h. The specific surface area was calculated from the measured N2 isotherm using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation applied in the relative pressure range (P/Po) of 0.01∼0.10. The total pore volume (Vtotal) was obtained from the N2 uptake at a relative pressure of P/Po=0.99. The average pore diameter is given by 4Vtotal/SBET. 2.4 HDO of guaiacol Catalytic HDO of 3g guaiacol diluted in 80ml solvent was carried out in a 200ml stainless steel batch autoclave under a 3MPa initial hydrogen pressure with 1g MoO2/AC catalyst or Mo2C/AC catalyst. All the substrates were tested at 553K for 3h. The effect of reaction temperature (553–613K) and solvents (Tetradecane, Dodecane, Decalin, Tetralin and Ethanol) were studied with MoO2/AC. After the reaction, the reactor was quenched to room temperature. The collected liquid products were detected by a GC/MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) equipped with a RTX-5MS column (30m, 0.25mm, 0.25μm) to analyze the constituent. The conversion and selectivity were analyzed with BEIFEN 3420A gas chromatograph-FID equipped with a SE-30 column (30m, 0.32mm, 1.0μm). For each liquid sample, 3 times of detections were performed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the materials The TPR profile illustrated in Fig. 1 shows mainly two H2 consumption peaks appearing at 770K and 920K, marked by dotted lines. The peak at 770K is attributed to the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2. The peak at 920K can be attributed to the carbonization of MoO2 to Mo2C over carbon surfaces. The X-Ray diffraction pattern of unreduced Mo/AC has peaks at 2θ of 23.3°, 27.3° corresponding to (101), (210) of MoO3 (ICSD 76-1003) and peaks at 2θ of 26.0°, 37.0°, 53.4°, 60.2°, 66.5° corresponding to (011), (020), (022), (031), (-131) of MoO2 (ICSD 73-1249),respectively (Fig. 2 ). It indicates that both MoO3 and MoO2 are existed in the unreduced Mo/AC catalyst. The formation of MoO2 can be attributed to reduction by the activated carbon in high temperature, although without hydrogen. The pattern for sample (b) has a number of peaks that can all be well-indexed to MoO2 (ICSD 73-1249) which indicates the Mo species are MoO2 after being reduced in the temperature of 873K with H2. Peaks of sample (c) can be well indexed to Mo2C (ICSD 72-1683) which indicates the Mo species are Mo2C after being reduced in the temperature of 973K with H2. What’s more, the crystal sizes of sample b and c were calculated to be 4.2nm and 9.8nm from the main XRD peaks using the Scherrer equation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to characterize the Mo chemical state. The Mo 3d X-ray photoelectron spectra of unreduced Mo/AC, MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC are shown in Fig. 3 . The chemical states of Mo species are summarized in Table 1 . For sample b, the doublet with a Mo 3d5/2 binding energy of 229.7 can be assigned to the formation of Mo4+ during H2 reduction. For sample c, the doublet with a Mo 3d5/2 binding energy of 228.2 can be assigned to the formation of Mo2C in 973K. This is in agreement with the TPR results. The TEM images in Fig. 4 illustrate the dispersion and particle size of MoO2 and Mo2C supported on activated carbon, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4a, b, the MoO2 particles (black spots) were well dispersed on the carbon support, and the average size of the particles was 4.41nm. As shown in Fig. 4d, e, the Mo2C particles (black spots) were well dispersed on the carbon support, and the average size of the particles was 7.07nm. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) gas sorptometry measurements were conducted to examine the porous nature of the catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of activated carbon, MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC. Specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were calculated and shown in Table 2 . Compared with the support of activated carbon, slight degree of hysteresis loops appears in N2 adsorption-desorption curves of both MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC catalysts. In addition, surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of both MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC catalysts increase slightly. It can be attributed to the redox effect of carbon with metal salt in the calcination process with high temperature, which consumes the carbon on the surface of the pore to make the pore size larger. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 HDO of guaiacol over MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC Hydroxydeoxygenation of guaiacol was measured over MoO2/AC, Mo2C/AC and without catalyst in the temperature of 573K with 3MPa initial H2 pressure for 3h, respectively. The conversion and selectivity were shown in Table 3 . Both MoO2/AC and Mo2C/AC showed good catalytic activity, but their selectivities were different. Catalyzed by MoO2/AC, phenolics including phenol and cresol were selectively produced. While the selectivity of phenol decreased from 72.0% to 28.9% and the selectivity of benzene increased from 0.6% to 39.4% with Mo2C/AC as catalyst. It indicates that MoO2/AC catalyst is a suitable catalyst for the selective formation of phenolics, since it show poor catalysis activity on the HDO of phenolic hydroxyl. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature on the HDO of guaiacol To research the effect of reaction temperature on the HDO of guaiacol catalyzed by MoO2/AC, a series of HDO reactions were carried with the temperature of 553–613K. The test results are shown in Table 4 and Fig. 6 . The conversion increased as reaction temperature increased, reaching almost 100% at 593K. For the selectivity of the reaction products, phenol as the main product, its selectivity decreased with increasing temperature, while the anisole increased with increasing temperature of 553K to 593K. This may be the reason that the difference of difficulty degree in breaking the bond between carbon(sp2)-OMe bond with carbon(sp3)-OAr bond decreased with increasing temperature. Naturally, the selectivities of deep HDO products including benzene, cresol, and toluene increased with increasing temperature. However, anisole and cresol reacted further backwards at the temperature of 613K, resulting in decreased selectivity. It was also noteworthy that the ratio of o-cresol to m-cresol increased with temperature for the reason of conversion of anisole to o-cresol increased with increasing temperature. 3.2.3 Effect of solvents on the HDO of guaiacol The effect of solvents on the conversion and selectivity of guaiacol was investigated over tetradecane, dodecane, decalin, tetralin and ethanol as shown in Table 5 and Fig. 7 . While ethanol was used as solvent, the aromatic ring was highly substituted by the alkyl group, and no HDO reaction took place. This result was more likely due to the competitive adsorption of ethanol with hydrogen on the catalyst surface. This is consistent with the results reported by Rui Ma et al., which indicates that hydrogen will slightly lower alcoholysis efficiency with alcohol as solvent [23]. Phenol was the main product when using tetradecane, dodecane, decalin, tetralin as solvents. Compared with alkane solvents, when decalin and tetralin were used as the solvent, the conversion of guaiacol and selectivity of phenol were remarkably improved. That can be attributed to that tetralin and decalin are hydrogen donor with respect to hydrogenation and HDO [24]. Especially, the selectivity of phenolics was up to 91.4% with tetralin as solvent. 3.3 Reaction pathways For the study of HDO pathways of guaiacol over MoO2/AC, HDO of 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, anisole, catechol and phenol were carried out in the same conditions as the HDO of guaiacol. These reaction results are shown in Table 6 . 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene was converted to cresol with a nearly 1:1 ratio of o-cresol and m-cresol and 5% of toluene was produced for further deoxidation. Anisole was converted to cresol, toluene, o-cresol and trace toluene with conversion of 16%. A summary of the HDO pathways of guaiacol based on the observed product distributions is proposed in Fig. 8 . Pathway 1 is a transalkylation process in which the methyl group on the methoxy group is transferred to the aromatic ring at the ortho position to produce 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene. One of the two phenolic hydroxyls was then hydrogenolyzed to generate o-cresol and m-cresol. Pathway 2 is the most preferred process, because the C(sp3)–OAr bond is most likely to be broken with the lowest bond energy. In this chain-breaking process, catechol and methane are produced in large quantities. Then catechol is easily converted to phenol completely. In pathway 3, the Ar-OMe band is hydrogenated to generate phenol and methanol. However, the fact of trace amounts of methanol was found in the product indicates that pathway 3 is not favored. In pathway 4, anisole is produced due to hydrogenation of C(sp2)–OH bond. Anisole can be further hydrodeoxygenated to produce phenol, benzene and toluene. 4 Conclusions The activated carbon supported MoO2 and Mo2C catalysts were prepared using incipient wetness impregnation method, and reduced at 873K and 973K in H2 flow, respectively. With the help of XRD, the Mo species in carbon-supported molybdenum catalysts were analyzed to be MoO2 and Mo2C, respectively. Compared with Mo2C/AC, MoO2/AC catalyst show poor catalysis activity on the HDO of phenolic hydroxyl so that phenolics can be selectively produced over MoO2/AC catalyst. Lower temperature is favorable for selective product of phenolics. Tetralin and decalin are better reaction solvents with respect to the hydrocarbon solvents. In the condition of 573K, 3MPa initial H2 pressure, with MoO2/AC as catalyst, more than 90% yield of phenolics was gained after 3h. Furthermore, HDO of guaiacol and its HDO intermediates including anisole, 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, were investigated in the same reaction conditions over carbon-supported molybdenum catalyst. Based on the observed product distributions, the HDO reaction pathways of guaiacol over molybdenum catalysts were proposed in which producing phenol from the HDO reaction of the intermediate catechol is the major reaction pathway. References [1] D. Wang S. Czernik D. Montane M. Mann E. Chornet Biomass to hydrogen via fast pyrolysis and catalytic steam reforming of the pyrolysis oil or its fractions Ind. Eng. Chem. coredata.dc:description: Activated carbon-supported molybdenum dioxide catalyst and molybdenum carbide catalyst were prepared by reduction in hydrogen with different temperatures. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol was investigated in 3MPa initial H2 pressure with these two catalysts. Phenolics were detected as the main products when catalyzed by molybdenum dioxide catalyst. Through analyzing the HDO selectivity of guaiacol and the intermediates including 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, catechol, phenol and anisole, the HDO reaction pathways of guaiacol over Mo-based catalysts were proposed. In the first stage, transalkylation and breaking of three CO bonds take place to produce 1,2-dihydroxy-3-methylbenzene, catechol, phenol and anisole, whereafter cresol, phenol, toluene and benzene are produced. Furthermore, the effects of reaction temperatures and solvents on HDO of guaiacol were investigated. Using tetralin as solvent, in 3MPa initial H2 pressure and at 573K, the conversion of guaiacol reached 98% with phenolics as the major product and the selectivity was greater than 91% after three hours of reaction time.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol to phenolics over activated carbon supported molybdenum catalysts
